revealed_symptoms.evolving: This thing keeps changing—getting darker, bigger, or just looking different than before.
revealed_symptoms.color variation: It’s got a bunch of different colors—like brown, black, maybe even some red or blue mixed in.
revealed_symptoms.border irregularity: The edges are all jagged, kinda messy, not smooth like my other moles.
revealed_symptoms.asymmetry: One side of this mole looks different from the other, like it's lopsided or uneven.
revealed_symptoms.diameter >6mm: It’s bigger than the eraser on a pencil, and I feel like it’s still growing.
revealed_symptoms.spontaneous bleeding: Sometimes this spot just starts bleeding out of nowhere, even if I don’t touch it.
revealed_symptoms.nodule formation: It’s kind of thick or raised, not flat like some of my other moles.
revealed_symptoms.induration: It feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin, like there's something under there.

hidden_symptoms.hyperkeratosis: There's this rough, flaky spot that won’t go away, and sometimes it peels.
hidden_symptoms.erythema: The skin around it looks red or puffy, like it’s irritated or reacting to something.
hidden_symptoms.telangiectasia: There are these tiny, spidery red blood vessels around the spot that I didn’t notice before.
hidden_symptoms.shiny or waxy bump: It looks kinda like a smooth, shiny pimple, but it never pops or goes away.

patient_history.content: Hi, I'll be your doctor today. What brings you in?

Well, I've got this thing on my skin that's been changing. It keeps getting darker and maybe bigger, or just looks different than it used to. It also has a bunch of different colors in it, like browns and blacks, and maybe even some red or blue. The edges are all jagged and messy, not smooth like my other moles. One side of it looks different from the other, kind of lopsided or uneven. And it's bigger than the eraser on a pencil. Sometimes it just starts bleeding out of nowhere. It's kind of thick or raised, not flat, and it feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin.

Thank you for providing that detailed information. It sounds like there is a concerning change in a skin lesion. Has this spot been itchy or tender at all? Also, have you had any history of significant sunburns or a lot of exposure to the sun?
No, it hasn’t been itchy or tender. And I wouldn't say I've had a lot of sunburns or been out in the sun more than anyone else.

Thank you for the additional information. Since the skin lesion isn't itchy or tender, and you haven't had any significant sun exposure, I want to know more about this spot. How long has this skin lesion been present, and has it always looked like this? Also, is there a history of skin cancer in your family?

I've had this spot for a while, but it definitely hasn't always looked like this. It's been changing over the past few months. As for family history, I don't know of any skin cancer, but I'll have to ask around.

Thank you. The fact that the spot has been changing over the past few months is significant. Do you happen to have any new moles or skin lesions developing anywhere else? Also, are there any other areas on your skin that you are concerned about?
No, there aren’t any new spots that I’ve noticed. I don't have any other areas that I'm concerned about, but this one is definitely worrying me.

Thank you for the additional information. Based on your description, I am concerned about the possibility of melanoma. Melanoma is a serious type of skin cancer that can be life-threatening if not caught early. Given the characteristics and changes you've described, it's very important that we take steps to confirm this. I want to schedule you for a biopsy to examine the lesion more closely and determine the exact diagnosis. We will discuss the results and treatment options after the biopsy.
Okay, a biopsy sounds good. What do I need to do?

It also has a bunch of different colors in it, like browns and blacks, and maybe even some red or blue. The edges are all jagged and messy, not smooth like my other moles. One side of it looks different from the other, kind of lopsided or uneven. And it's bigger than the eraser on a pencil. Sometimes it just starts bleeding out of nowhere. It's kind of thick or raised, not flat, and it feels thicker or harder than the rest of my skin.

The next step is to explain the procedure to the patient and schedule the biopsy.","known_symptoms":["changing skin lesion","darker skin lesion","skin lesion size increase","skin lesion color variation","jagged edges","asymmetry","bleeding","raised or thickened skin lesion","lesion changing over months"],"diagnosis_rankings":[{"diagnosis":"Melanoma","confidence":0.85},{"diagnosis":"Dysplastic Nevus","confidence":0.4},{"diagnosis":"Basal Cell Carcinoma","confidence":0.2}],"symptoms_to_verify_or_refute":[],"diagnosis_relayed_to_patient":true,"response_to_patient":"I'm glad that you are ready to move forward with a biopsy. To prepare for the biopsy, you don't need to do much. I'll numb the area around the skin lesion with a local anesthetic. Then, I will remove a small sample of the lesion. I will then send the sample to a lab to be examined under a microscope. The results usually take a few days to come back. We will then discuss the results and any necessary treatment options. I will schedule you for the biopsy as soon as possible. Does that sound acceptable to you?"}
